content.description: Think you climb 9+ / try this one. Super wild stuff.
content.location: Do Understatement to the ledge. Go up to bolt then out the flake/roof. Several roofs and cracks await you on the adventure to the top.

content.description: At the far left end of the cliff are three vertical jam cracks. This is the route on the right in the corner.
content.location: Far Left End

content.description: The route starts on the left side of the center amphitheater.  Follow an easy rotten groove till you see a bolt on the slab below nightflyer.  second pitch goes up the often wet painfully obvious gully above you.  Be careful of loose rock and munge.
content.location: Center of the cliff.  Approach as for heavy weather sailing.

content.description: A thin steep crack with a few flexible and wafer thin face holds. Tread lightly. A tricky and possibly spooky start protected by a small nut, followed by fun overhanging face climbing and maybe a layback or two leads to a beautiful mantle move from a small left facing corner onto the sloping ledge; though bomber gear is at the climber's hip, a tall climber could hang a draw on the chains above from a jug for the security of a TR on the last moves. The X marked flake, though helpful for a solid left hand, is Unstable and moves when pressure is applied.
content.protection: The gear is bomber if you are efficient and strong enough to place it. Bolt anchor and chains. Small to "suasage finger" size cams. A small nut is useful for the first moves off the boulder.
content.location: Located on the far left hand side of Band-M are three short vertical cracks. Over Done is the left hand crack. Rappel from chains.

content.description: This route is just to the left of Hercules. Start on the left side of the wall and climb past 2 bolts to an anchor.
content.location: Far Left End

content.description: A short but worthwhile route. Athin layback crux and good anchors. Bring some brews if it's warm.
content.protection: small gear and a pin. Tree belay
content.location: Thrash along the base to a small buttress with a very steep crack system on it's right (Jungle Work), Malt is around the corner, aright facing  corner.

content.description: A tough one ! Nice groovy slabbing leads to a hard finger to fist crack up a steep wall. The initial 5.10 groove can be done on it's own with a belay to the left.
content.protection: wires to 4" or so. tree anchor
content.location: Center of the cliff , right of Jungle work and Malt Therapy A big streak of orange lichen is at the start.

content.description: Formerly the hardest 5.10 in NH- brian was way strong. The steep crack(thin and thin -hands) right of Malt Therapy. Pretty hard and watch out for bee's
content.location: Thrash along the base to a small buttress- the line is pretty clear.

content.description: One of the 10 best routes in NH. Just awesome climbing-technical, good gear with work and strenno.
content.location: On the right side of the crag is kinda an alcove thing. Dogs starts right and up to some horizontals. Then left to a belay. Fire off the thin crack off the belay.

content.description: Climb the overhanging wall past four bolts to a chain anchor. The route is just to the left of Over Done.
content.location: Far Left End

content.description: Well, I am surprised no one have posted up this classic. An absolute kicker climb. Powerful and technical.
content.location:
Above the ramp on Standard Route is an obvious big overhanging flake. Hard underclings and a very tough move at the end. From atop p1 a thin crack goes to the top. 

  Tom Callaghan's legendary Gale Force 10+ XX is the left hand finish.

content.description: The route follows the awkward center crack. This route is togher than it looks. The crux is at the top.
content.location: Far Left End

content.description: There are almost no moderates at this cliff and when I saw this one in the guidebook I was hoping to find a hidden gem. To put it nicely, it has a lot of potential, but unfortunately dirt and plants keep this route from being a good moderate option. Climb the obvious twin cracks straight up, battling through some ferns in the crack on the left. Continue up the dual cracks to a leafy top out, taking care not to slip. Belay on a tree. Altogether I think this could be really cool if it got cleaned, as it would be cool to have another Firebird or Kiddy Crack in the valley.
content.protection: Standard rack, doubles in the larger sizes.
content.location: From where the approach trail meets the wall, take a right and hike up and right past Bandit, round the corner and head slightly uphill where you will see twin cracks on the left with some vegetation.

content.description: Ah 5.9+, what a grade. This is another moderate route hidden in plain sight that doesn’t get much attention. Dream Time starts 40 feet right of the big Standard Route ramp. A small tree marks the start. Face climb up to a bulge, then trend right. Look for a hidden pin by some shrubbery, then continue more to the right. A tricky mantle onto the slab will hold your attention as you pull over to easy ground above. Continue up to the spike belay, bring up your second or just thread and lower from here.
content.protection: Standard rack and a fixed pin to a spike anchor.
content.location: Starts on the steeper face about 40 feet to the right of the 5.4 Standard Route ramp.

climbs.name: Doggie Style
climbs.fa: B. Parrott, S. Damboise, B. Rugo, H. Breilmann

content.description: This is the bolted route to the right of The Understatement. The route is pretty self explanatory, climb past 3 bolts on the overhanging arete to the 2 ring anchor. This stays mostly dry in the rain.
content.protection: 3 bolts. The first bolt is fairly high so you may want a stick clip.
content.location: This route is on the overhanging arete to the right of the left facing corner (The Understatement 5.8).

content.description: This route is directly above OVER DONE. It is the finger crack on the overhanging block with a giant roof. There is an old peg at the bottom.
content.location: Far Left End

content.description: Good Barber Wall style face climbing. Sunny! Good early season and late season.
content.protection: Draws and small cams. Gets spooky without the cams.
content.location: Scramble up and left of the Butcher Block area. Obvious bolted line.

content.description: If you've ever walked to the left end of Band M on a rain day and wondered "is that thing a route, wonder no longer. Black Plague climbs the dirty, left facing black corner you pass on the way to the left end. Climb the corner awkwardly for 40 feet, through dirt and lichen streaks to the ledge above.
content.protection: Standard rack with doubles in hand-fist sized pieces.
content.location: The obvious black corner, a little ways before you reach the sport routes, is an obvious black streaked corner.

content.description: This is one of the better single pitch jamcracks of its grade in the Mount Washingtom Valley. Continuous hand-jamming up a round edged crack in a big left-facing dihedral. Exit left to a ledge before the top of the cliff, where you can rap off a tree with one rope, or continue to the top and bushwhack right to walk off.
content.protection: There are a few pitons but it takes bomber gear the whole way. Rap off a tree on a ledge before topping out, or walk off right.
content.location: On the right end of the cliff, 50 feet or so right of the route Three Wogs, where the approach "trail" reaches the crag. Three Wogs is identifiable by three spaced bolts in a shallow groove. You can't miss Bandit if you're on the right side of the cliff.

climbs.name: Animal Crackers
climbs.fa: Dick Peterson, Brad White, Jose Abeyta

content.description: Another obscure moderate at this cliff. This one is much more inviting than it's vegetated neighbor Ermite but could still use some more traffic. Climb easy moves to the obvious left facing corner. Follow the corner up and left to a hand crack. Jam and stem up the rough crack until you can pull over the top of the cliff (watch for pine needles). Belay from trees.
content.location: From where the approach trail meets the cliff walk up and right, past the beautiful crack (Bandit) around the corner to where you'll see a few cracks. Animal Crackers starts just right of the twin cracks (Ermite) at a left facing flake).

climbs.name: [Redacted]
climbs.fa: FA: Michael Hartrich, Joe Cote, Albert Dow May 1981

content.description: This is the first climb you come to if you follow the traditional approach trail.  3 bolts in a shallow groove mark the climb.  Climb the groove to a ledge .10a.  Then follow a beautiful hand crack out a flare .7 to the top.
The routes on the cliff
